content.description: Sit start on the right-leaning line of crimpy holds. Pull up and grab the huge undercling. Use this to get up to the large pinch to the right to top-out
content.location: Middle of the northwest face of Turtle Rock. The undercling is one of the larger features on the rock.

content.description: Turtle Rock Traverse is an eighty foot traverse starting at the northwest corner of the rock on an obvious head high flake.  Two cruxes and a twenty foot section of slopers to finish.  The landings are great with a couple of pads.  The top of the rock is off for the basic traverse and a harder low variation also exists.  Beautiful location - especially at sunset.
Short and sweet right-leaning crack with plenty of feet
content.location: Right-leaning crack just right and below the high part of the southeast face of the rock

content.description: Sit start on the flake on the far left side of the North Face. Transverse right on some semi-slopy rails into The Flake. Finish by topping out The Flake.
content.protection: The wall isn't very high on this side. You don't even really need a crash pad. However, one maybe useful for piece of mind.
content.location: Follow a semi-paved road going right from the parking lot. Turn right at the top of the hill onto a dirt road. The problem is on the North Face of Turtle Rock.

content.description: Solid jugs throughout. Can be a bit harder with a sit start. Either way, grab a huge hold to get up and over to the slabby topout
content.protection: Crashpad and spotter, or could be top-roped
content.location: Straight up the southeast (highest) face of Turtle Rock

content.description: Start with underclinging holds, follow decent holds up and over to a slabby, somewhat slipper and scary section.
content.protection: Crash pad and spotter. Topout is scary. Could be top-roped.
content.location: The far left side of the SE face of Turtle Rock. Just to the right of the arete which is the southernmost part of the rock.

content.description: Use the arete on the right and slipper footholds to ascend the southwest face.
content.protection: Crash pad + spotter. Top-out is a little scary
content.location:
The far right side of the SW face of Turtle Rock, just to the right of the more popular Fool's Gold which avoids the arete.

If you have a compass on you, this arete is the southernmost point of Turtle Rock

content.description:
This problem is featured in Bay Area Rock, but it is super forgettable. Stand start on the sloping rail and from there top out.

beta video
content.location:
Five feet right of the

crimper

.

content.description: Shared start with The Flake. Sit start w/ right side-pull. Climb up to the right along the seam.
Start on a shelf. Make a long reach to the giant undercling. Mantle.
content.location: The Reach is on the right side of the boulder. Look for the obvious giant undercling.

content.description: Start on the slippery pedestal with your hands on the two jugs, then right hands underclings the top of the circle, right foot bumps, left foot stems out to a good edge out to the left, left hand then reaches high out left for a rectangular knob. et voila!
content.protection: please don't fall on the spike

content.description: Start on the big flake-like hold. Not the main flake. Pull up to an intermediate hold then top out.
content.location: About 10 feet to the left of the prominent flake on the northwest face.

content.description: Sloper shelf into a mantle. (Don’t forget to check out the view behind you.)
Climb up the slight overhang, find a big jug about two thirds of the way up. It's a bit like a side pull but facing straight into the wall.
content.location: Right side of the high part of the southeast face

content.description: Yabo start crossed hands low on a rail with holes in it. Sparse feet and a high left foot will get your left hand to an intermediate. Bump to the jug flake. Finish direct to crimps and a sloppy top out. One move wonder down low.
content.location: North west corner of the Turtle. Starts near a bulge really low to the ground.

content.description: Begin at the South Eastern extreme of Turtle.  There is a flake that juts out and points towards Angel Island at the base.  There are two small moons right next to each other right above this flake.  Use these moons as the starting hand holds, and use the flake as the starting foot hold. Start traversing counterclockwise (the next move should be to a downwards horn underneath an outcropping out the rock. Traverse until you come to a cavity in the rock. This should be at the other side of the outcropping of the rock.  Begin ascending.  Go above the out cropping where there should be an abundance of nice holds.  Harmony bears slightly left here, you're on the route if on your left there is a pretty nice horn and you have to come close to a hand-foot match to get to a pseudo-rail for a foot hold. finally on your right is a really nice bucket at the top of the rock. You'll have to search for this bucket with your hand for a little bit, but once you find it you'll fall in love with it. Mantle and top out. You should be at the highest part of Turtle Rock.  Why did I name this Harmony? As soon as you go over the outcropping, there is an intense moment of pure bliss and peace.  When I first sent this problem, at this moment, it seemed as though I was no longer a separate entity from the rock, but rather a new part of it.  I rarely find this kind of genuine and infinite focus and oneness with anything other than on Harmony.  It is certainly not the most difficult or technical of bouldering problems I have ever done, but it is by far and away the most spiritually inspiring problem I have ever done (hence my obsession with Turtle Rock).
content.protection: A crash pad is all you need, it is a little high, but the higher parts are the easier parts of the problem

content.description: Climb up polished slopers and edges to the top
content.location: Right side of the arch of the mini cave

content.description: Low stand start and climb the semi highball line. Tiny crimpers and a pocket or two.
content.location: On the opposite side of the boulder as the flake. Left of the arete.

content.description: Sit start at the base of the flake w/ a right hand side-pull. Continue up the flake

Standing start from the end of the right-facing rail of crimpy holds. Rather than the huge move straight to the pinch (the reach) go right and find a series of small crimpy holds to work up to the top with.
content.location: Just right of the the large pinch at the top middle of the northwest face of Turtle Rock.

content.description:
Sit start on very crimpy holds. Pull up to a solid hold in the middle and then to the top-out. Much easier with a standing start a bit higher up.

There are a few eliminates for this problem up to about V6.
content.location: Sit start just left of the large, landmark flake
